title: IELTS Listening Test 14

questions.instructions:
Questions 1 and 2
Choose the correct letter A–C.
questions.question: The travel agent:
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. can personally recommend Vancouver. The travel agent says "Vancouver is lovely this time of year" which shows personal recommendation. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: thinks Europe is a good destination
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the travel agent mentions "There are also some special deals for Europe," this is just presenting an option, not a personal recommendation. The agent specifically says "Vancouver is lovely this time of year," which shows a personal recommendation for Vancouver (Canada), not Europe.
Correct! The travel agent says "Vancouver is lovely this time of year" which demonstrates a personal recommendation based on knowledge of the destination.

mc_options.text: does not think America is a good choice
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The travel agent never suggests America is not a good choice. In fact, they enthusiastically recommend Vancouver (in Canada, which is in North America) and say "Vancouver is lovely this time of year."

questions.options:
thinks Europe is a good destination
can personally recommend Vancouver
does not think America is a good choice

questions.question: The customer:
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. knows people living in Canada. The customer says "I have some relatives over in Vancouver" which shows they know people in Canada. In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: is going to Europe next year
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While the customer mentions "I can always travel around Europe next year," this is just a possibility, not a definite plan. The customer is actually booking a trip to Vancouver, Canada right now.
Correct! The customer says "I have some relatives over in Vancouver" and later mentions "I have a cousin I can stay with," which clearly shows they know people living in Canada.

mc_options.text: wants to go to the warmest place
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The customer never mentions wanting to go to the warmest place. They mention being interested in North America (specifically Canada) or Europe, and that they're "on quite a tight budget," but warmth is not mentioned as a factor.

questions.options:
is going to Europe next year
knows people living in Canada
wants to go to the warmest place

questions.question: Who is the speaker addressing?
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is D. people buying second homes. The speaker says "I understand that you all own your own home, and some of you may be interested in buying additional property here in the city." In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The speaker is not addressing property agents. The speaker says "My company deals with finding property" and "One of my main roles within the company is to find investment properties," which shows they work as a property agent, not speaking to other agents.

Incorrect. The speaker is not addressing people selling houses. The opening states "I understand that you all own your own home, and some of you may be interested in buying additional property," indicating the audience wants to buy, not sell.

Incorrect. The speaker mentions countryside as a topic but isn't addressing people who live there. The talk is about "property here in the city" and the speaker says "some of you may be interested in buying additional property here in the city."

Correct! The speaker begins by saying "I understand that you all own your own home, and some of you may be interested in buying additional property here in the city," which clearly indicates the audience already owns one home and may want to buy another (second home).

questions.question: Lisa Brown believes
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is B. there is a psychological factor involved in owning your own home. The speaker says "House ownership gives us a feeling of having achieved something" and "It can give us a sense of security," indicating psychological/emotional benefits. mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The speaker says "It is most people's dream to, one day, own their own house," which describes a dream/aspiration, not a statement that most people will actually achieve homeownership. The talk also discusses how buying is "very difficult and often impossible" for many young people.

questions.question: Property in the countryside is becoming more popular because
questions.no_answer_feedback: The correct answer is C. the concept of the home office means that some people don't need to go into work. The speaker says "More and more people are beginning to work from home which means they can avoid the hustle and bustle of rush-hour traffic jams." In the IELTS test, you should always take a guess. You don't lose points for a wrong answer.

mc_options.text: people want to get away from the city
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. While this might seem plausible, it's not the specific reason given. The speaker states the reason is work-related: "More and more people are beginning to work from home" which allows them to "live in a more rural and peaceful location."

mc_options.text: some parts of the city are becoming overcrowded
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. The speaker mentions "more and more people are competing for houses" in the city center, but this is not given as the reason why countryside property is becoming popular. The actual reason relates to working from home.

mc_options.text: the concept of the home office means that some people don't need to go into work
mc_options.feedback: Correct! The speaker says "our style of work is changing" and "In certain professions, for example sales and computing, it is no longer necessary for people to be based in an office full-time. More and more people are beginning to work from home" which allows them to choose rural locations.

mc_options.text: public transport is beginning to serve outlying areas
mc_options.feedback: Incorrect. Public transport is not mentioned in the talk. The speaker explains that working from home allows people to "avoid the hustle and bustle of rush-hour traffic jams into work," which is about not commuting, not about better public transport.

questions.options:
people want to get away from the city
some parts of the city are becoming overcrowded
the concept of the home office means that some people don't need to go into work
public transport is beginning to serve outlying areas

sections.transcript:
Section 1 TRAVEL AGENT: Hello. Welcome to the Flight Depot. How can I help you? CUSTOMER: Well, I'm looking for a reasonably priced holiday. I went to South Africa for a month last year and I'd like to see North America this time – maybe Canada, but I'm also interested in Europe if the prices to Canada are too expensive. I'm on quite a tight budget you see.

TRAVEL AGENT: Well I can certainly get some prices for Canada for you. Q1Vancouver is lovely this time of year, and we have some special offers on at the moment. There are also some special deals for Europe.

CUSTOMER: Okay, well, Q2I have some relatives over in Vancouver so that would be good. I can always travel around Europe next year.

TRAVEL AGENT: Right, let's have a look at some prices then. When would you like to go?

CUSTOMER:Some time at the end of the end of next month if possible, but I'm quite flexible anytime between the 24th to the 31st. Q6I'd like to go for three weeks.

TRAVEL AGENT: Well there's lots of availability for those dates. Now, if you're concerned about the cost, it's cheaper if you don't mind not flying direct. CUSTOMER:Sorry? What do you mean? TRAVEL AGENT: Well, if you don't mind changing planes then it's cheaper. CUSTOMER:Oh, well, I don't mind changing planes. TRAVEL AGENT: In that case, the cheapest flight I have leaves on the 25th and changes in New York. It's only a short stop – you'll be in the airport for two and a half hours. How does that sound? CUSTOMER:Sounds good, but what's the price? TRAVEL AGENT: That's £412 for a return flight, but that doesn't include airport tax. Would you like to arrange any accommodation? CUSTOMER:No, I have a cousin I can stay with. All I need is the flight, so I think I'll take that one. TRAVEL AGENT: Right, I'll just check availability for your return. Three weeks did you say? CUSTOMER:Yes, that's right. TRAVEL AGENT: Okay...well there are seats available on the 14th or the 15th. Which one would you prefer? CUSTOMER:The fifteenth sounds good. Yes, from the 25th to the 15th sounds fine. TRAVEL AGENT: I'll reserve that for you then. Can you tell me your name please?

CUSTOMER:Sandra Q3Jackson.

TRAVEL AGENT: Is that J-A-C-K-S-O-N? CUSTOMER:That's right. TRAVEL AGENT: And can I take an address and contact number? CUSTOMER:Yes, it's 10, Allen Road, Oldham. Do you want a home number or my mobile? TRAVEL AGENT: Either's fine.

CUSTOMER:Well, my home number is 0151 Q4433 398

TRAVEL AGENT: Great. Now, one more thing. Do you have any Q7travel insurance? We recommend all our clients take some kind of cover, even though most people don't end up needing it. Most people have it just for peace of mind.

CUSTOMER:Well, what times of cover do you have?

TRAVEL AGENT: Our most comprehensive cover is the Q8Gold Star, which will cost £21 for the period you are away. It's a good policy because it covers almost all eventualities, even extreme sports such as snow boarding and skydiving.

CUSTOMER:Well, I don't plan to do anything that dangerous, but £21 sounds fine so I'll take that too please. TRAVEL AGENT: Great. Is there anything else I can help you with? CUSTOMER:Well, do you have any information about what to do in Vancouver? TRAVEL AGENT: Yes, I'm sure there's something on the computer that can help. Ahh, yes. CUSTOMER:There's a Shakespeare play at the theatre, but it's quite expensive. That starts at 8pm. The city museum is really popular too, if you like that kind of thing. They have a special exhibition of Japanese armour next month. Entrance is free and the museum is open from 9.00 to 4.30 Monday to Saturday. Would you be interested in either of those? TRAVEL AGENT: Oh, well..errr, maybe. (sounds hesitant)

CUSTOMER:Well, I'm sure you can arrange that when you get there anyway. So, it's the flight and the Gold Star insurance. That's… Q10£433 in total.

TRAVEL AGENT: Can I pay by visa? CUSTOMER: Yes of course. If you start…. (fade out)

Section 2

Thank you very much for inviting me here today. l understand that you all own your own home, and Q11some of you may be interested in buying additional property here in the city, so I hope you will find the information l am going to share with you useful and informative. I am going to talk about the situation with property here in the city. The city centre of any area is obviously going to have the highest prices and as more and more people are competing for houses in this area, Q12both renting and buying are becoming increasingly difficult.

It is most people's dream to, one day, own their own house. House ownership gives us a feeling of having achieved something and we can see clearly what we have worked so hard for all our lives. It can give us a sense of security for our old age and a knowledge that we will hopefully have something to pass on to our children. However, buying a house, particularly for first-time buyers, Q13is becoming more and more difficult, not only due to increasing prices but also because of the need for a substantial deposit. For younger people, buying their first home is very difficult and often impossible. Young couples who cannot get the deposit together, need to rent for a long time and sometimes forever. While, traditionally, homes near the centre of the city have been the most desirable, people are now looking further afield. This has happened for a number of reasons, the main one being that our style of work is changing along with that of other countries such as the USA. In certain professions, for example sales and computing, it is no longer necessary for people to be based in an office full-time. Q14More and more people are beginning to work from home which means they can avoid the hustle and bustle of rush-hour traffic jams into work and have more freedom to choose to live in a more rural and peaceful location.

My company deals with finding property for both purchasers and renters in the city area. One of my main roles within the company is to find Q15investment properties for people who wish to plan ahead for their future.

An investment property is usually at the Q16cheaper end of the market. People buy investment properties, not to live in, but in addition to their own home in order to rent it out to other people.

The advantage of putting your savings into property for the future is that you can be pretty certain that, as a long-term investment, your money will safely increase in value in line with inflation. Many people are turning to property investment instead of Q17pension schemes as we hear the horror stories of countries such as the UK, where people have invested all their lives into their pension schemes to find that now their money is relatively worthless.

Houses automatically earn what is known as capital gains; that is, for every year you own the property, it becomes more valuable and often gives a better rate of interest on your money than most banks do. However, that is not to say there are no risks. There are people who buy property when the market is high and prices are inflated beyond their true value, only to find that when the housing market slows down, they are in a state of Q18negative equity. Negative equity is a situation that arises when you owe more for the house than the house itself is worth.

In short: the best advice is to be aware of the ups and downs of the housing market. Property investment, if handled correctly, can be Q19enormously satisfying. I hope that this has given you an insight into the basics of the property market. Thank you for listening. Please Q20raise your hand if you have any questions and I will try to be of assistance.

Section 3
Interviewer Q22Thank you very much for tuning in today to listen to our weekly hour on conservation issues. Last week we spoke about the impact of environmental changes on primates, and this week to continue the theme we have invited in a specialist by the name of Professor Andrew Ripley, all the way from Q23USA, to tell us more about the problems faced by the cat family. Professor Ripley, thank you very much for joining us today.
Professor Ripley lt's my pleasure, thank you very much for inviting me.
Interviewer 50 l understand that you spent a great proportion of your time travelling the globe and monitoring changes in population levels of the cat family.
Professor Ripley Yes, that's correct. Of course we are not talking about the domestic cat here, but their majestic cousins such as the lion, tiger and jaguar to name but a few.
Interviewer Which member of the cat family do you yourself find to be the most fascinating?
Professor Ripley Well, l've spent Q21a lot of time recently studying jaguars, but the lion is still my personal favourite. lt is the world's most social cat and unusual in the way in which it chooses to group together with others of its species. Q24Prides of lions basking in the sunshine are probably one of people's most vivid perceptions of the African bush.
Interviewer Yes certainly ... l totally agree with you. Can you tell me the current lion population in Africa these days?
Professor Ripley Well it is very difficult to measure it accurately. Figures range from 100 000, to as few as 30 000, but it is generally estimated that there are Q2550 000. In order to maintain the population and protect the species from poachers, many are moved to protected areas.
Interviewer Which member of the cat family do you feel is most at risk?
Professor Ripley For different reasons, a number of species of the cat family are endangered. Sometimes due to natural predators or environmental changes, but mainly because of the threat of Q26hunters. For example, I am sure you are aware, the bones and body parts of tigers have been, and still are, traditionally used in medicines in the Far East. Because of this and the demand for medicine made from tiger parts, their numbers have been falling for some time and to date -there are fewer than Q276000 tigers living in their natural habitat of the forests and plains of Asia.
Interviewer What is being done to curb the population decrease?
Professor Ripley Well, specialists such as myself work closely with conservationist groups such as the World Wildlife Federation, or WWF, to protect tigers from illegal hunting. WWF considers the drop in tiger numbers to be catastrophic and they are working hard to conserve the populations in China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam and Russia.
Interviewer I understand that poaching is not the only problem faced by the leopard... let me get this right is it the snow leopard which lives in the mountains in Asia?
Professor Ripley Yes, it is. Poaching has been a problem, but not the most important. its natural prey—the animals it hunts — is declining too. its natural habitat in high—altitude areas, specifically the pastures, is threatened by the growth of Q28agriculture. lt is this that is causing the main problem for the snow leopard. It is going to be extremely difficult for numbers to recover, but again the WWF has been working hard to continue to fund projects to aid the snow leopard in Q29Nepal and Pakistan, and hopefully Bhutan very soon.
Interviewer Well this is fascinating information you are giving us, Professor, we are just going into a short commercial break. When we come back l have a few questions for you about the puma and the jaguar. Remember listeners, there will be an opportunity to phone in and voice any opinions or questions you may have for the professor Q30in ten minutes.

Section 4

Announcer: Good afternoon. l'm pleased to see so many of you here today. As I told you all on Monday, the lecture on overpopulation has been postponed until next week as we have Q31a guest speaker today. l'd like to introduce you all to Donald Mackenzie, who has recently returned from a 12-month research project in America. He is here to share with us some of the results of his studies into the problem of illiteracy.

Donald Mackenzie: Hello. Now, as sociology students, I have no doubt that you are aware that it is commonly believed that one indicator of a developed country is the level of education of its citizens. Most of these nations have free compulsory education for all and strict teacher certification requirements, so it would logically follow that people from countries such as America would be highly educated. Yet this isn't always so: in America alone, 42 million adults Q32cannot read and 50 million can recognise so few printed words they each have the reading ability of a Q3310-year-old. Frightening statistics indeed, but not as frightening as the trend suggested by current estimates — the number of illiterate adults is increasing by approximately Q34two and a quarter million people each year, and although global statistics have not been compiled, it suggests an extremely disturbing figure.

Inevitably, this is having an impact on employment. In America, the annual cost in welfare programmes and unemployment compensation due to illiteracy stands at Q35six billion US dollars, and an additional $237 billion a year in unrealised earnings is forfeited by people who lack basic reading skills. There is also the cost of post-school literacy programmes, which have been put in place in order to counter this increasing figure. A conservative estimate places the cost of these programmes at Q3610 billion dollars each year, and growing steadily.

Moving on, l'd like to talk about some of the causes of this increasing illiteracy. Children were taught to read by, first learning the alphabet, then the sounds of each letter, how they blended into syllables, and how those syllables made up words. They were taught that English spelling is logical and systematic, and that to become a ﬂuent reader it was necessary to master the alphabetic code in which English words are written, to the point where the code is used automatically with little conscious thought given to it. To make myself clear, I mean readers could sound out the letters, spelling them phonetically. Once a child learned this ability, attention could be turned to more advanced content. It seldom, if ever, occurred to teachers to give children word lists to read, or to make beginner-level readers memorise whole words before learning the components of those words, or to memorise whole stories as today's proponents of the whole-language approach recommend. Q37Several recent studies have found that 90 per cent of remedial reading students in developed countries are not able to decode fluently, accurately, and at an automatic level of response. The currently used 'whole language' method was originally conceived and used in the early 1800s to teach the deaf how to read, a method which has long since been discarded by the teachers of the deaf themselves as inadequate and outmoded.

English is an alphabetic language that, when written, uses letters to represent speech Q38sounds. When students were taught to read, they consciously identified the speech sounds and learned to recognise the letters used to represent them. They were then trained to apply this information to decode the names of written words, understand their meaning, and comprehend the information presented as a complete thought. The English language contains approximately half a million words. Of these words, about 300 compose about three-quarters of the words we use regularly. As I said, in schools where the 'whole language' method is taught, children are constantly memorising sight words during the first three or four grades of school, but are never taught how to unlock the meaning of the other 499 700 or more words.

Whole-language learning causes frustration, poor Q39spelling and hostility towards reading. Very bright children who can't memorise long lists of words and retain their meaning are placed in special education, when all they need is to be taught the 26 letters of the alphabet, the 44 sounds they make, and the 70 common ways to spell those sounds. Some researchers believe dyslexia and the symptoms of Attention Deficit Disorder are actually caused by this reversal of the normal learning sequence.

So why do faulty reading methods continue to be used? Well, in short it's Q40Big Business! The sale of instructional reading programmes is big business today: each year publishing companies compete for the adoption of reading programmes and workbooks which have to be replaced annually. Concentrating on phonics would seriously reduce the cost of education.
